subtitle: Place your advance order now on Amazon for the very first volume of the New Thinking
Allowed Dialogue Series, Is There Life After Death?
Publication date is June 1st.
Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Our topic today is gender transformation.
My guest, Samantha Danielle Caputi, is a friend
and colleague of several years. I know her
as Dani. Dani has been a guest on New Thinking
Allowed three times previously, talking about
such diverse topics as psychic weather control,
the mind-body problem and sense of identity,
and the use of random event generators and
parapsychological testing. Dani has a doctoral
degree in atmospheric science. She's based in the San Francisco Bay Area in Northern
California and now I'll switch over to the
internet video. Welcome, Dani. It's a pleasure
to be with you again.
Yeah, thanks for having me back.
We're going to talk about a very different
topic than we have in the past, and I'm sure
it's going to get very personal, so I want
to let you know I'm very grateful that you're
willing to open up about, well, we don't know.
I mean, I don't know what's going to come
up, but I thought a good starting point would be your childhood.
I was born in 1992 to two wonderful parents
in New York, Long Island, and I grew up there,
and around five or six years old, I would say, I was exhibiting certain developmental
issues, and eventually I got diagnosed on the autism spectrum. I was already not on
a track to fit in growing up, and as I progressed
into my late elementary, early junior high,
I began to develop a gender dysphoria, so I
was born male, and I felt very, very dysphoric
about that in terms of not feeling like my body is developing in the way that I wanted
it to, and I wanted to ultimately do something
about that, whatever that treatment would
look like.
There's a lot more I could talk about about my childhood, but that's since we're here
to talk about trans issues, I figure that's a good place to start.
How old would you say you were when the gender dysphoria became evident?
Yeah, so I would say that I experienced it a bit between starting around age five, so
very young, and that's very typical what you
see in the media. Jazz Jennings is a famous
case of who has a whole reality TV show, but
where gender dysphoria develops from a very,
very young age. I had a little bit at a young
age, but for me it was more during puberty
when it accelerated, when it became worse.
Well, gender dysphoria sounds like a clinical
term, and I'm sure there's a lot of literature
about it, but can you be more specific about
how that felt to you, what your inner experience
was like?
Totally, yeah. So, gender dysphoria, I talk about that in the clinical sense because I
actually don't really like the identity-based
model of transgenderism, as I'll say. So,
a lot of times nowadays we hear people talking
about being transgender as an identity, something
you identify as or identify with, and that is
of course part of the equation, but I think
the focus on that has kind of led a lot of us
down the wrong path in terms of understanding
what it actually is. So, for example, it leads
to these metaphysical, speculative questions
about what it, quote unquote, really means to be a man or really means to be a woman,
and then we get into the differentiation of sex versus gender, and there's this whole
debate about, some people say that if you differentiate those and say gender is what
you socially present as whereas sex is biology,
then you're by definition enforcing stereotypes,
and then there becomes other questions about
what is a woman, which is a documentary that
was released last year, and I think there is legitimate criticism in terms of some of
the people from that interview not really able to provide a definition, but really to
me the characteristic of being transgender is
gender dysphoria, which is a medical condition
that I just so happen to experience, and the treatment for that is to, or one of the
treatments for this, this isn't the right
treatment for everybody, but the right treatment
for me was to undergo medical procedures and
to take cross-sex hormones to look and resemble
the opposite sex to the extent medically possible,
so I don't go around saying I am the same
as a biological woman, I instead just live my
life as if I were one to the extent possible,
and that is, was in my case the best treatment
for the gender dysphoria that I had, the deep
unsettling feeling I had about my body, and in
a lot of cases, people should be evaluated prior
to starting this treatment because it is intense,
and a lot of it is irreversible, and so to be
properly evaluated that this isn't just escaping
from another kind of condition, and then somebody
would later regret transitioning, those things
have to be teased apart in the beginning to the
extent possible, so that's why it's important,
that's why I use the terminology gender dysphoria
to describe the experience. Even though that's
a clinical sounding term, I think that's really
how we have to be thinking of this issue rather
than the identity-based model that the current
ideologies push. Well, what I'd like to do is go
back, and if you can remember, what it was like
for you was let's say a 12 or 13 year old boy. How
did that feel? What were some of your experiences
at that time that led you to become the person you
are now? Around 12 or 13, 13, 14 when puberty was
accelerating, I remember one of the first things
I noticed was really being uncomfortable with
the hair I was developing and the lowering of my
voice, and I would even ask teachers, I was like,
oh is it normal to like, I don't really like the
the hair on my legs, I don't really like the fact
that I'm growing body hair, and pretty much the
response I got was, oh no, you should love it,
that's, you know, yeah. And so it was kind of this
discontinuity between what I was experiencing and
what I, you know, was told I should be experiencing
in terms of my feelings about puberty. And so I,
you know, did kind of some research online. I
actually had a wonderful teacher who actually
at the time because of my autism spectrum disorder
and I was having difficulty like focusing in class,
so she would kind of be there to like, you know,
help me stay focused. She did really wonderful
research actually on my behalf and then came back
to me and said, actually some of these things I
was telling you was not correct, you know, this
is a condition called, you know, gender dysphoria
wasn't really a common word, transgender wasn't. But
I was kind of pointed to these online communities
of people who experience that condition. And
I didn't spend a whole lot of time on it, but
I knew that was what I was experiencing and
that I really was not supposed to grow up to be
in a, you know, masculine looking body, right?
I didn't want to grow, the thought of growing
up into an adult like male with like, you know, a
beard and, you know, all the stereotypes associated
with that just really just disgusted me to my
core. And so, yeah, so I went to my parents,
they found a good therapist who didn't right away
affirm me, right? Because I think that's important
too. There's this notion that, you know, anybody
experiencing this should be blindly affirmed.
And I don't think that's the case. I think people
should be evaluated prior to starting treatment.
But I didn't go under any treatment as a, you
know, in my puberty years. It was really just
kind of dealing with those feelings of dysphoria
for, you know, and I dealt with them kind of for
another four or five years before I started
actually acting on it. And it wasn't until I
moved to California in my early 20s when I begun
the journey of medical and social transition.
I'm under the impression, and correct me if
I'm wrong, that, and I know this is a very hot
button issue, I suppose politically, that it's
actually a good thing to start the transition
earlier rather than later. Yeah, so there is
some truth to that, but we have to look at it in
context, right? So back in, you know, the, I'll
say, you know, 80s and 90s, roughly, when, you know,
treatment and awareness of gender dysphoria started to rise, you would sometimes get
people presenting at a very early age with gender
dysphoria, prominent gender, more than I had at
an early age, and they would be treated with
puberty blockers and then later cross-sex hormones
and surgery once they're an adult. Usually,
puberty blockers would start at around age 12.
And for a while, it was working okay in the
sense that there was not a whole lot of regrets,
but recently there's this term in the literature
called rapid onset gender dysphoria, which I,
actually, I don't think that's a very precise name
for what it is, but it's this idea that there's
this social contagion that, with females in
particular, right, girls going through puberty,
it's very common, for instance, when they're
developing breasts for them to feel uncomfortable
with it, for them to feel like, you know,
something's not quite right. And in the past
few years, really 10 years or so, I want to
say, is when there's been more of a surge of
that group presenting at gender clinics. And
I think, unfortunately, the kind of the blind
affirmation of that has led to a lot of the
cases of regret we see today. However, so it is
so I would say the idea of transitioning kids,
and plus there's all sorts of side effects with
puberty blockers, you know, this idea that they're
completely reversible is just not entirely true,
right? So we have to really look at that in the
context of a risk benefit analysis for specific
individuals. And I think another thing that can't
be ignored with that is, you know, it makes sense
because of the influence of big pharma, you know,
they're going to want to push more drugs when they
can. I mean, we saw that recently with recommendations
that came out for people as young as 12 who have
obesity to undergo weight loss surgery, and not
even necessarily try to change their their diet
lifestyle. And so it kind of baffles me almost how the, you know, I'll say,
you know, in general, the political left, it's
not everybody on the left. It's also some people,
but in general, it's the political left has,
you know, the supposed party of anti corporatism
has somehow become, you know, a bootlicker for big pharma almost, in this sense.
I do also want to say that once somebody is an
adult, it is probably, yeah, it's almost definitely
better to transition as a young adult than as
an older adult. It'll yield better results.
Some of the preliminary data on, you know, long
term side effects from using hormones is suggesting
that starting a new set of hormones in that
period will minimize long term health risks.
And it's just it's just better to think of transition in terms of a life plan,
rather than, you know, unfortunately, for a number of people, they, you know,
live their life as men for several decades, and then they hit this crisis, you know,
and then they transition and then they're not
always happy because they missed some of their
younger years. Do you have any data regarding the
percentage of people who go through the transition
and then regret that they've done so? The classic
numbers reported in the literature kind of
range from like 0.1 to 1%, but a lot of that
is lagged. A lot of that is before we had this
tsunami of, you know, young girls who are just
starting puberty presenting to these gender
clinics. So we don't, we're not going to have
updated data on that for another few years.
I mean, we can't because this is kind of a new
phenomenon and where, you know, we have to follow
up on those patients and then it takes longer
to publish studies. In any case, your transition
started, as you told me earlier, the physical
transition. You were in your early 20s and I
gather that you feel that that's not a bad time.
That might even be optimal. Wait until you're an
adult before making, you know, life-altering
decisions. That's not to say that no person,
again, it has to be an individual risk-benefit
analysis, you know. It's not to say nobody
younger would ever benefit from treatment, but
I think the threshold has to be a lot higher.
I recently interviewed a 72-year-old woman and we're having this
conversation about female elders in the
psychedelic community. The topic came up that
some of them felt totally neglected, like being
female could make you a second-class citizen. I
always felt, for example, I had privileges that my sisters didn't have growing up.
So, I can understand why young girls would want to
become male. I think, though, for a male to want
to become a female does sort of mean a diminution
of social status. That's a good point, but I do
think that it depends on the case, right? So, people that transition very young,
somebody like Jazz Jennings, who has always lived as female, or as if she was female,
is not really going to experience male privilege
at all. But we can't also ignore the cumulative
effects, right? So, if somebody lived their life
as a male for several decades and was able to
go from, you know, keep getting promoted at work,
things of that sort, they've accumulated all this
male privilege and some of that gets lost when
they transition, but not all of it. So, I wouldn't
say it's accurate to say that when we transition
we lose all of our male privilege, but it really
depends on when we transition and the prior life
experiences we had to that. And I just want to
actually talk about that for another moment, is
this idea of, you know, females feeling erased
and, you know, second-class citizens, because
a lot of women are starting to get, you know,
quite frankly, fed up with, you know, as they'll
call it, men pretending to be women, or, you know,
trans women is the proper term. And, you know,
just to kind of speak to that group for a minute,
it's like, I understand the concerns and I am, you know, whenever I see, for example,
TikToks that go viral of, you know, trans people, like mocking women, or, you know,
somebody going from straight male transitioning
to become, like, lesbian woman saying, like,
you know, you have to date us or you're transphobic, that's another common trope.
There's, you know, this idea that you can just be
trans by self-ideating, like, you know, you don't
have to experience dysphoria, you know, and
concerns that women have with, like, over female
spaces and restrooms. I understand those concerns
given how prominent these, you know, cases have
been of people exhibiting this predatory, like,
behavior. And I just want to say that, you know,
in terms of the community, I think we need
better accountability, especially particularly
in the male to female trans community, particularly
even the subgroup, the older transitioning
male to female category, specifically the ones
that are attracted to women, right? It's like,
we have to realize, like, there is that power
dynamic there that could put women in a position
where they feel unsafe, and we have to have
better accountability so that we can actually
come to, you know, discuss things like, okay,
how do we deal with sports? How do we deal with
self-idea? At what point can somebody say they're
a woman? And an example I use of this is that
in the Black community, there's this talking point that gets said a lot
about the Black community, which is like, oh, what
about Black on Black crime, which is really just
a distraction from the, you know, the notions of
police brutality and, like, the systemic issues.
But the Black community has formed organizations, many organizations,
that address Black on Black crime, in addition to
fighting for systemic issues. The idea is you can
do both. You can both acknowledge the systemic
things that need to change and, you know, systemic
oppression, and also hold accountability for
yourselves and do what you can to improve your
own situation. You know, we just need more of
that in the trans community. That's really,
really lacking right now is this accountability
aspect. It's all, you know, the victimhood. It's
all this social justice side, which is fine as its
own thing, but it's on the spectrum, right? So we
have to find the right balance. And as of right
now, the activists are kind of enabling this
bad behavior, enabling people that are flat-out
mocking women to speak for all of us. And,
yeah, and I think there just has to be better
in-community accountability so that we can have
proper conversations and both address the systemic
issues as well as having that accountability.
I'm old enough so that I remember, I think it would have been back in the early 60s,
Christine Jorgensen I think may have been the
first male to go through the surgery and become
female. And Christine Jorgensen became very
famous, but it was such an unusual phenomenon,
like this was the first person in the world, as
far as I knew, to transition. And the very idea
that it was possible was a novelty. Now you have,
I think in an earlier conversation you and I were
describing that maybe as much as 1% of the
American population has gone through a transition.
We're talking about millions of people. So even so, it's still in the early stages.
Obviously, the culture as a whole is very unsettled around this.
Yeah, and, you know, in the past couple years, I
mean, there's been this anti-trans push. There's
a website I found, translegislation.com, that
tracks what they call anti-trans bills. Now,
not necessarily every bill in there I'm against,
because, you know, I'd have to read all the
individual bills. And like I said, there's some nuanced issues about self IDs, sports,
when the right age for kids are. But there are
other bills that are, you know, pushing restrictions
for transition well into adulthood. And there's
just online, like I'm just seeing in YouTube
comments in the past couple months, you know, even
on conservative channels, where this stuff is,
you know, people in the past have talked respectfully about trans people. And now,
you know, the dialogue has shifted, you know,
people are clearly getting angrier. And I partially
I partially blame the media for that for kind
of featuring the most cringe, the most unhinged,
you know, trans people. Obviously, they want
to cause division among the population. I mean,
the mainstream media, that is. But I do think, you
know, there's still, again, that accountability
factor. And without that, you know, people might
look at, you know, these crazy activists saying
that, you know, date us or you're transphobic.
There was a video like that a male to female
trans person made about a week ago, threatening
violence if she's not allowed to use the women's
restroom. And so it's like, you know, it's
understandable that people that are fence sitters
are going to look at that and go statements like
we should eradicate transgenderism from public
life entirely. That almost seems reasonable in
comparison. And they're almost compelled to that
side. And, you know, me saying this is not saying
we should lick the boots of transphobes or like
the, you know, the far right that doesn't want us
to exist. No, it's not saying, you know, a lot of
people say that like, Oh, so you're you guys are
saying if you just make a better argument, if
you're just a little bit nicer to the Nazis,
then, you know, they will, you know, then they'll
respect you. And it's like, No, that's not.
That's not what it is. The reason I'm into this
respectability politics, as they call it, is because
of those fence sitters that are not engaged in
the fight, we have to, if we want to get them
over to our side, we have to have that balance of
accountability. I know a lot of people, particularly on the right wing side of the
political spectrum, talk about freedom. They want
to be free in all regards to say whatever they want
to. You might even say that in extreme cases,
they want to be free to kill people if they
feel threatened by them. And there's a lot of
legislation, the Stand Your Ground laws and so
on. They give people license to do exactly that.
And it dawns on me that why shouldn't any person
be free to define themselves any way they want in
terms of gender or sexuality, assuming that it is
hard and is not harming other people. Exactly.
Well, you know, they are, you know, people are
free to do that. And I agree, people should
absolutely be free to, you know, call themselves
whatever they want, you know. But when we're
talking about certain things like, okay,
you know, should somebody who looks like you, Jeff,
be able to just say, I feel like a woman today and
then use the women's restroom. You know, I think
we could both agree there should be some boundaries
on exactly, you know, where that line is when it
becomes recognized in society, into law, right?
You know, sports is another classic example of
like, you know, if somebody can just self-ID
into it. And, you know, the other thing I
want to say is people might take this as like
anti non-binary, anti, you know, 86 genders or
whatever. I'm not against that stuff. It's just,
don't speak for me as a, you know, transsexual
person who experienced dysphoria and medically
transitioned. You know, if you're saying like,
oh, you don't need dysphoria to be trans, right?
That's a common saying now. And it's like, okay,
well, sure, call yourself transgender if you want,
just don't speak for, don't speak for people
who've had dysphoria, you know, and I actually
think that might be where, you know, we kind of
reclaim, you know, trans people with dysphoria
might want to reclaim this word transsexual because
so many people are identifying as transgender now
who don't necessarily have dysphoria. They're
welcome to do what they want with their physical
presentation and identify how they like.
It's just when it comes to like speaking over
people in the community who've had these, you
know, dealt with dysphoria for years, that's when
it becomes an issue. It's like be as free as
you want as long as you're not stepping on other
people, right? You mentioned earlier that you were
diagnosed at a much younger age of being on what
you call the autism spectrum. Was that in any way
related, do you think, to the gender dysphoria?
You know, there is some literature out there about autism spectrum disorder and
later onset gender dysphoria, so they could be related. I've heard a hypothesis about
mirror neurons being put out there before, and
this actually gets really interesting because
now we're getting into the science of like what
makes somebody trans, what actually causes gender
dysphoria, and there is a huge controversy in
academia that started, well, let's give the
background first. In the late 80s, early 90s, there
was a sexologist by the name of Ray Blanchard,
and what he proposed was that, and it was
based on some earlier work, it wasn't entirely
a new idea in the sense, but it was this idea
that you can group people who are transgender
into two categories depending on their sexual
orientation. So in one group, let's just say,
just to keep this simple, we're talking about
males who transition to women, but keep in mind
there's a mirror image for women who transition,
so for males who transition to women,
there's one type which is homosexual with respect to their birth sex. He calls these
homosexual transsexuals, and this is basically
people who tend to transition very young,
or they experience gender dysphoria very
young, and they are very naturally feminine.
If they're going to school as a boy, a lot of people are calling them
cistis or slurs like that because they're
just naturally very feminine, right, and they
have, well, I don't know, the brain studies get weird, but that might be kind of the
classic presentation you hear about a female
soul in a male body, and they will transition
typically at the very latest in young adulthood.
Then there's this other type which consists of
males who are either bisexual or straight with
regard to their birth sex, so people who are
basically males who are attracted to women, and
they'll experience gender dysphoria later in life.
Usually it'll develop as a teen. It might start
very early, but it'll develop through puberty,
and they often transition later in life, and they often hold very masculine jobs
for many, many years. Now this idea that there's these two types wasn't really new,
but it was the labeling, right? He called the
homosexual type, he called them homosexual
transsexuals. For the heterosexual type, he called
that heterosexual or bisexual type, he called that
autogynophilic transsexuals. There's now this
term autogynophilia, which literally translates to
love of oneself as a woman, which he proposed is
this motivation for this group of heterosexuals
transitioning in the sense that they just have
this fetish. They just basically have a fetish
for seeing themselves as women and then transition. Then this homosexual type, it's
almost less stigmatizing because they're at least
acknowledged as having female souls in that sense,
but the label homosexual transsexual is almost
no less stigmatizing. The trans community
did not like this categorization at all, and it
actually kind of flew under the radar for a while
until 2003 when another sex researcher named
Michael Bailey published a book called The Man
Who Would Be Queen. This is what stirred up a
firestorm of controversy. There were a bunch
of trans activists saying that basically this is
slandering the entire community and all of that.
Some of them went as far as actually doxing
the researchers and trying to get them removed
from their positions at universities. Then you
have the sex researchers on another side saying
this is just academic freedom. It's like we should
be allowed to publish things even if you don't
exactly like what it is. This stirred up this
entire controversy. In order to kind of bridge
this gap between the trans community and sex
researchers, because those things can both be
true. We want academic freedom, but we also want
to not harm the trans community with our studies.
How can we bridge that gap? One of the ways is
we should probably change the terminology in
the literature. Like I said, homosexual transsexual
or autogynophilic transsexual, those terms
are kind of stigmatizing. If they're stigmatizing
but they're accurate, that would be one thing,
but I think there is also a lack of accuracy too.
For the autogynophilic subtype in particular,
it might be true that some of them transition
because of this fetish as Blanchard originally
talked about. For a lot of other of them, it'll
kind of start in their teens as them maybe having
this fetish or this unusual sexual orientation
where they want to kind of become the thing
that they desire. If that makes sense, they want to become what they're attracted to.
That's I think actually a more accurate way
of describing it is having this dimension of
your sexual orientation where you're attracted
to women, but you also want to become what you're
attracted to. You want to be with what you're
attracted to as well as become what you're
attracted to. It might be correlated with
fetishes earlier on in transition, but ultimately
most people in that group transition due to gender dysphoria. Actually Deborah So,
famous sex researcher now, she has a book called
The End of Gender where she actually makes this
distinction pretty well I think. I'm not in the
camp of basically entirely defending Blanchard.
I think that the way he went about making this
two type was somewhat reckless in the sense that
for this entire group, what he called the autogynophilics, he didn't recognize that
for a lot of them gender dysphoria is why they
transition. Ultimately, even if they've had
fetishes earlier in life, ultimately the cause
of their transition is the gender dysphoria.
That's at least the proximal cause, similar to the homosexual transsexual subgroup.
So I'm actually working on a paper right now that
I hope will recontextualize this two type framework
in a way that kind of makes everyone a little bit more happy. That will
bridge this gap. It'll not ignore any data coming from the original studies because I
do ultimately think that this two type categorization is correct, that you can
cluster trans people in these two groups. But I contextualize it in a way that
says that basically you get these two modes on this continuum where you're going to get
gender dysphoria depending on someone's sexual
orientation and what we call an erotic target
inversion. Erotic target inversion is basically,
like I described before, that's probably a better
term for autogynophilia because that would imply fetish, but erotic target inversion
implies it's more of a sexual orientation, which I think is more accurate. It's that
there's this dimension of orientation just like
intensity is one dimension where you could be
very hypersexual or very asexual. Direction is
another dimension. Are you attracted to the same
sex or the opposite sex or somewhere in between? That's a spectrum. And then also
the erotic target inversion is a dimension. And so the mistake that I think
Blanchard made was assuming that the erotic
target inversion only goes in one direction.
I propose that it can be both positive and negative. So you have erotic target
inversions and erotic target repulsions. I'm
playing around with those terms a little bit,
but if at that point, if you kind of map it out,
it would make sense that you get two clusters of
people experiencing gender dysphoria. And then all of the data is fine. It just
recontextualizes the model. And I think it
satisfies Occam's razor better because it's really,
instead of these two entirely separate causes of
gender dysphoria, you just have one underlying
cause, but it's just a result of being at two places with different combinations of
these sexual orientation dimensions. Lately, I
hear a term being used quite a bit in the media,
LBGQT, which suggests they're lumping together
a lot of different groups. And even within each
of those initials, there are probably many
subgroups who all get lumped together. They're
part of one category that needs some sort of,
I suppose, special consideration in terms of
discrimination and equality laws. But I've also
heard that there's a lot of conflicts between
these various subgroups. I have a friend who's a gay activist who expressed to me on
one occasion that he and other gay AIDS activists,
as it were, feel some resentment towards the trans
people because they're getting all the attention
these days, but they haven't spent all the decades
working for equality the way other gay activists
have done. Yeah, in-community resentment is a
huge issue, and it's made worse by the fact that
we're not allowed to have conversations sometimes.
It's like you're either for trans or you're not
in that in-group. How do you have conversations
with people in the community about how can we...
Because if any two people have resentment towards
each other, the only way of resolving that is having conversations, talking it out,
saying, okay, how can we make this work? As long
as that's not allowed to happen, as long as there's
barriers to conversations, then I don't really see
